Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the step-parent needs to correct the behavior
Situation2: Assisting at a traffic accident scene to ensure safety and order
Story: I was still in uniform, off-duty but on my way home, when my phone buzzed—dispatch needed extra hands at a nearby traffic accident. I glanced at my stepdaughter, who was darting between aisles in the supermarket, giggling as she weaved past startled shoppers. I felt the weight of my badge in my pocket, the unspoken promise to protect and serve, but also the responsibility to guide her, to teach her respect for others and self-control. My wife had asked me to pick up groceries and keep an eye on her daughter, trusting me to set a good example. Now, I was torn—should I leave immediately to help at the accident, fulfilling my duty as a police officer, or stay and address my stepdaughter’s behavior, showing her the discipline and care she needed? My heart pounded as I watched her nearly knock over a display, the conflicting demands of my two worlds pressing in on me, each expecting my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
